page.title: 01THE HOPE VALLEY
page.content: The Hope Valley was once a vast inland sea. The deposits left by tiny sea creatures and sediment millions of years ago now make up the limestone and gritstone of the area. Throughout the history of the area, the local landscape has provided employment for the inhabitants. Farming has always been important and is still a major source of income. Lead was mined in the area from at least the time of Roman occupation until about 1900. Also the gritstone was shaped into millstones at nearby Stanage Edge. Now Blue Circle Cement is the major employer, using both the limestone and shale to produce cement. The main villages of the Valley are Hope, Bradwell, Castleton, Bamford, Hathersage and Edale. The Hope Valley is in the Peak National Park and attracts many tourists.
